CatDescriptText: Mr. William Owens, retired Westinghouse worker, Homewood and William Hampton, postal worker, Terrace Village 2, were part of the Pittsburghers Speak Up column published in Pittsburgh Courier Newspaper, March 11, 1961, pg. 7  with question: "Do you think Negroes over-emphasize "social life" as it pertains to entertainment?  If so, can you suggest a remedy for "curing it."  Mr. Owens' answer reads: "No, we do not."  Mr. Hampton's answer reads: "I don't think so.  We are entitled to some typo of entertainment.  I think everybody is entitled to some type of entertainment, because it's normal to life."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of William Owens wearing light colored fedora with dark band, eyeglasses, and light colored overcoat, standing in front of KQV radio, Smithfield Street, Downtown; Portrait of William Hampton wearing dark hat, moustache, and dark flecked overcoat, standing on sidewalk with Drake-Kapphan Pianos in background, Smithfield Street, Downtown
